The number of shots attempted by Portuguese soccer team FC Porto in Wednesday's final of the UEFA Europa League, against SC Braga. Porto scored a goal on that one attempt and won the match, 1-0.

headline: China Accuses Ai of Tax Evasion
summary: China has accused detained artist-activist Ai Weiwei of evading "a huge amount" of tax through a company he controlled, in the most detailed explanation yet of the charges against him.

headline: Camel-Trekking Across the Gobi
summary: The vast and otherworldly Gobi Desert stretches across 500,000 square miles of both Mongolia and China's province of Inner Mongolia. Surprisingly, it can be a comfortable, accessible place to travel, says Journal reporter Stan Sesser, who recently spent a week exploring the region.

headline: Cultural CEOs' Pay
summary: Here's a look at the total compensation packages for some of the highest-paid top executives at cultural institutions that receive significant subsidies from city taxpayers

headline: Obama Backs Bipartisan Resolution on Libya
summary: President Barack Obama invited Congress to approve U.S. intervention in Libya, expressing "support" for a bipartisan resolution drawn up by a group of senators authorizing the military operation.

headline: Regulators Shut Three Banks
summary: U.S. regulators announced the failure of two more Georgia banks, extending the state's position as the most failure-plagued state in the country this year, and said Washington state saw its first bank fail since November.

headline: Beery Brooklyn Brunch
summary: Beer meets brunch at Strong Place, a rustic bar and bistro in Cobble Hill.

headline: Bomb Targets Americans in Pakistan
summary: A roadside bomb exploded near a pair of U.S. consulate vehicles in northwest Pakistan. A Pakistani passerby died in the attack.

headline: Critics Hail Admission of Chinese Dam Flaws
summary: Critics of China's Three Gorges dam said an unusual government statement this week acknowledging serious flaws in the project could provide ammunition to those opposing other hydropower projects in China.

headline: Fitch Cuts Greece; Investors Retreat
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Greece's credit ratings three notches, citing the scale of the country's challenge in securing solvency. Yields on peripheral euro-zone government bonds rose and investors bought safe-haven German government bonds.

headline: Comcast Queried on FCC Hire
summary: The chairman of the House Oversight Committee wants more information from the FCC about the departure of commissioner Meredith Attwell Baker for a lobbying job at Comcast.

headline: Shell Approves World's First Floating LNG Project
summary: Royal Dutch Shell approved construction of a giant vessel designed to chill natural gas for export at sea, the first such vessel approved anywhere in the world, allowing it to tap gas deposits stranded hundreds of miles from land.

headline: Holman Jenkins: Sam Zell's Nightmare Continues
summary: Can those who sold Tribune stock four years ago be forced to give the money back?

headline: Dow Closes Down 93 Points
summary: Concerns about a potential restructuring of Greek debt and troubling profit reports from Gap and Aeropostale weighed on investor sentiment.

headline: Weak Link to LinkedIn
summary: None

headline: Trading in Lehman Bankruptcy Claims Set Record in April
summary: A record number of bankruptcy claims against Lehman Brothers traded hands last month as buyers grew more optimistic about how much they could recover on the claims as the failed investment bank is wound down.

headline: Democratic Governors (Heart) Taxes
summary: The trend is unmistakable. Taxes are rising in blue states and falling in the red states this year, contributing to a widening disparity in tax burdens across the country.

headline: An Awkward Photo Op
summary: President Barack Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke with reporters Friday afternoon after a two-hour meeting that lasted much longer than originally scheduled.

headline: Fashion's Interior Inspiration
summary: While spring is abloom outdoors, some designers looked inside for ideas for the season's collections. Here are eight spring looks and the interior decoration items that inspired them.

headline: Brazil Won't Propose Candidate to Lead IMF
summary: Brazilian Finance Minister Guido Mantega said Friday that his country won't necessarily oppose a European candidate to succeed Dominique Strauss-Kahn at the helm of the IMF.

headline: Oil Settles Above $99 a Barrel
summary: Crude futures settled higher as buyers re-entered the market ahead of contract expiration and traders remain convinced that long-term demand for oil was on the rise.

headline: SEC Names Chief Economist
summary: The SEC named Vanderbilt University economist Craig M. Lewis to become its chief economist, filling a key post that has been left vacant for more than a year.

headline: Liberty Could Open New Chapter With Barnes
summary: Liberty Media's bid for Barnes & Noble could open a new chapter for the media conglomerate, as the bookstore business is a departure from its concentration on television and e-commerce investments.

headline: Investors in Lehman-Linked Bonds Vote for Payout
summary: Investors in Hong Kong who lost money from minibonds linked to collapsed investment bank Lehman Brothers voted overwhelmingly to accept an offer to recoup up to 96.5% of their investments.

headline: Ann Inc.'s Profit Rises 21%; Margins Shrink
summary: Ann posted a 21% earnings increase and raised its full-year sales estimate, though the clothing retailer's margins contracted.

headline: Protests Halt Aetna Meeting
summary: Aetna's annual shareholder meeting was temporarily halted by protesters calling for health-care reform. The meeting resumed a few minutes later, and police were called to the scene at a Philadelphia hotel.

headline: Natural Gas Bounces Back from Six-Week Lows
summary: Natural-gas futures erased Thursday's sharp losses, rising more than 3% as buyers re-entered a market at prices that had fallen to their lowest level in almost six weeks.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Friday's pictures, a protester hurls stones in the West Bank, strong men pull a ship in Estonia, Tepco's president resigns in Japan and more.

headline: Gold Ends Above $1,500
summary: Gold settled above $1,500 a troy ounce for the first time in six trading days as investors sought to hedge against weaker equity markets and concerns about the euro.

headline: LinkedIn Leads Tech Shares; Apple Slips
summary: Strong gains at Salesforce.com and LinkedIn gave the tech sector a boost, though Apple slipped on reports of an explosion at a plant in China that makes some of the company's products.

headline: Photos of the Day: May 20
summary: In today's pictures, a protester hurls stones in the West Bank, strong men pull a ship in Estonia, Tepco's president resigns in Japan and more.

headline: E.U. Approves Blood Thinner From Bristol-Myers, Pfizer
summary: European health regulators approved a new blood thinner from Pfizer and Bristol-Myers Squibb for the prevention of blood clots in people who have undergone hip or knee replacement surgery.

headline: The Cost of a New Jersey Public Education
summary: The Christie administration released its calculation of how much districts spend per pupil. The figure now includes spending that varies per district, such as federal funding, debt and transportation costs, and is several thousand dollars more on average than previous similar figures.

headline: Yingli Green's Profit Rises
summary: Yingli Green Energy posted higher first-quarter earnings and affirmed its full-year sales target, though disruptions in Europe's solar maket are hurting business.

headline: Greece's Upbeat Downgrade
summary: Fitch's latest downgrade of Greece is the closest Athens has come to good news from a ratings agency since the start of the euro-zone crisis.

headline: European Shares Feel Weight of Greek Downgrade
summary: European stocks fell as Fitch downgraded Greece's credit rating. Japanese shares dropped as utilities declined, while Indian shares climbed.

headline: Balancing Act
summary: House Republicans are starting to rally behind a strategy on the debt ceiling called "cut, cap and balance."

headline: Spanish PM: Reforms Must Continue
summary: Spanish Prime Minister José Luis Rodriguez Zapatero said the continuing youth protests across the country are "understandable," but he vowed to continue the overhauls to fix the country's ailing economy

headline: Union Pacific CFO: Flooding to Trim Volume
summary: Union Pacific Chief Financial Officer Rob Knight said Friday that disruptions from the Mississippi River flooding likely will reduce the railroad's May freight volume by about 1%.

headline: IMF Calls for New EU Debt Plan
summary: The EU needs to devise a whole new "comprehensive plan," including boosting the scale of aid, if it is to solve the debt crisis facing Ireland and other countries using the euro, the IMF said in a staff report.

headline: JB Chem to Mull Sale of Stake in European Units
summary: JB Chemicals and Pharmaceuticals' board will meet on Monday to consider selling part of its business in Russia and neighboring countries, which constituted the former Soviet Union, after a review of the business.

headline: Dervis Won't Seek Top IMF Role
summary: Kemal Dervis, the former World Bank official and Turkish economy minister who was seen as a potential candidate to replace Dominique Strauss-Kahn as head of the IMF, said he wouldn't put himself forward for the job.

headline: Greek Downgrade Hits European Stocks
summary: European stocks fell Friday and posted a loss for the week, as Fitch Ratings downgraded Greece's credit rating, rekindling euro-zone debt worries.

headline: The End of the World: FAQs
summary: Is it true? No. With a few accounting tricks, we can keep going well past May 21. That, and answers to other frequently asked questions about the end, in Reply to All.

headline: Doctors Attach Ceramic Implant to Giffords's Skull
summary: Rep. Gabrielle Giffords had a ceramic implant attached to her skull this week, along with a tube under her skin that drains built-up spinal fluid, as she continues to make a "miraculous" recovery from an assassination attempt four months ago, her doctors said.

headline: Portugal Election May End in Deadlock
summary: An inconclusive result in next month's general election could leave Portugal rudderless at a time when urgent action is needed to restore order to the country's finances.

headline: Euro-Zone Confidence Improves
summary: Consumer confidence across the euro zone improved unexpectedly in May after the currency area's economy grew more than expected in the first quarter, data from the European Commission showed.

headline: Libya Offers Conditional Withdrawal
summary: Gadhafi's government offered to withdraw the Libyan army from cities it has occupied if NATO stops bombing and rebel forces agree to disarm.

headline: Photos of the Day: May 19
summary: In today's pictures, floodwater fills farms in Mississippi, President Barack Obama speaks on Middle East policy, children peer out from behind a U.S. flag in a Pakistan slum and more.

headline: Kim Jong Il Said to Visit China
summary: North Korean dictator Kim Jong Il went to northeastern China by train on Friday, his third trip to the neighboring country in the past year.

headline: IndiaThis Week
summary: Celebrations of Buddha Jayanti, visit by President of Uzbekistan , protests against POSCO and more.

headline: Drought-Hit Spain Seeks Early Farm Subsidies
summary: Spain has become the latest country to apply for early European farming support subsidies this year as poor weather continues to threaten harvests across the region, a spokesman for the European Commission said.

headline: Portugal Sharply Lowers Its Budget Deficit
summary: Portugal said its budget deficit fell sharply in the first four months of 2011 from a year ago, as it continues to take steps to meet the targets set under its $111.63 billion bailout.

headline: Traders See Profits in Tweets
summary: Ever on the lookout for new ways to make money, intrepid traders and investment managers have begun using social-networking data in their trading strategies.

headline: Honda Gives Assurances to Dealers
summary: Honda Motor told its U.S. dealers that July vehicle deliveries would increase by 11% from June levels and accelerate in August as the auto maker recovers from Japan's March disaster.

headline: Knot to Head Dutch Central Bank
summary: Klaas Knot, a director at the Dutch finance ministry, will succeed Nout Wellink as the head of the Dutch central bank in July this year, the Dutch minister of finance confirmed.

headline: Pandora's Shares Tumble as Earnings Disappoint
summary: Danish jewelry maker Pandora A/S was punished hard by investors after its results fell short of expectations and revealed weaknesses in its key German and Australian markets.

headline: ITC Net Profit Rises 25%
summary: ITC exceeded market estimates with a 25% jump in fourth-quarter net profit, driven by strong performances across all its businesses, but investors were disappointed as its operating margin shrank sequentially.

headline: Monsoon and the Indian Economy
summary: A good monsoon season is crucial for the Indian economy. Some snapshots.

headline: BP Still Mired in Legal Uncertainty
summary: BP has settled all legal claims with MOEX Offshore 2007, a subsidiary of Mitsui & Co which owned 10% of the Macondo well ruptured in last April's oil spill. Hope should be contained, however. In itself, the settlement is arguably a disappointment.

headline: Tata Steel Makeover Threatens 1,500 U.K. Jobs
summary: Tata Steel has announced a five-year, £400 million restructuring program aimed at turning around its loss-making European long products division, a move that may result in 1,500 U.K. job losses.

headline: Merkel Praises Lagarde
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel praised French Finance Minister Christine Lagarde, but stopped short of openly supporting her as a candidate for managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Indian Shares Higher for Second Day
summary: Indian shares ended higher for a second consecutive session Friday as Larsen & Toubro added to the previous day's gains on the back of robust quarterly earnings, while interest rate sensitive shares rose ahead of the May derivatives expiry next week.

headline: Bengal for Business?
summary: Mamata Banerjee, the Trinamool Congress leader and newly elected chief minister of West Bengal, in her election manifesto had promised a range of measures to promote the state's economy. Opening up the former Communist-ruled state to business could prove to be a daunting task. Here are some snapshots of Bengal's recent business track record.

headline: Kanimozhi Arrested in Telecom Case
summary: Indian investigators arrested lawmaker Kanimozhi Karunanidhi and a corporate executive after a special court rejected their bail pleas in one of India's biggest corruption cases.

headline: Deutsche Bank Denies Bid to Hurt Kirch
summary: Deutsche Bank executives defended the bank in court Thursday against accusations that it triggered the collapse of a German media conglomerate, the latest in a series of legal confrontations that have tarnished the bank's image.

headline: Thai Airways Plans New Budget Carrier
summary: Thai Airways' board approved in principle a plan to set up a new budget airline, after its plan to establish a joint venture with Singapore's Tiger Airways ran into regulatory hurdles.

headline: Monsoon to Reach Andaman Late
summary: Monsoon rains are unlikely to reach India's Andaman and Nicobar Islands for at least the next two days, weather department officials said, adding that the delay won't impact the timely arrival of the seasonal rains over the mainland through the southern state of Kerala.

headline: Berlin, Vienna Torpedo Nuclear Stress Tests
summary: Germany and Austria have blocked a plan backed by several European Union countries that would have set criteria for nuclear-reactor safety checks to protect against natural disasters.

headline: Glaxo, Human Genome Sciences Win EU Backing for Lupus Drug
summary: Human Genome Sciences and GlaxoSmithKline said European drug regulators backed their lupus drug Benlysta, boosting prospects for the first new medicine for treating the debilitating disease in more than 50 years.

headline: BOJ Stands Pat on Policy
summary: The Bank of Japan decided to keep its easy monetary policy on hold despite news the day before that the country's economy contracted at a faster pace than expected in the first quarter due to the March 11 earthquake.

headline: Hutchison Whampoa Chairman to Consider Listing Assets
summary: Hong Kong's Li Ka-shing, chairman of Hutchison Whampoa, said he will consider listing the company's assets separately, although spinning off the highly profitable retail businesses has been ruled out.

headline: World Telecom Day
summary: On World Telecom Day, a look at the development of the sector in India.

headline: IPL Roundup
summary: Kolkata Knight Riders defeated Pune Warriors by seven wickets to all but seal a spot in the Indian Premier League play-offs.

headline: Utility Uncertainty Hits Tokyo Market
summary: Japanese stocks fell as utilities declined on uncertainty over the future of the power sector, while Indian shares climbed 1%.

headline: Saab Denies Bribe Claim
summary: Swedish defense and aerospace company Saab denied making any direct payments to a South African government adviser to help finalize the sale of Gripen jet fighters in the early 2000s.

headline: Government to Sell Stake in Scooters India
summary: India's federal cabinet has approved selling the government's entire stake in Scooters India, said Information and Broadcasting Minister Ambika Soni.

headline: Jet in Talks for Sale and Leaseback of Boeing Planes
summary: Jet Airways is in talks with leasing companies to sell and leaseback some of its Boeing planes, a senior executive said.

headline: A Network to Help Start-Ups With a Cause
summary: A social-sector advisory firm has launched a platform to bring together rich individuals, foundations and companies keen on investing in businesses that cater to the poor.

headline: Demographic Dividend or Debt?
summary: With India's GDP growing at an average of 8% over the last decade, there is widespread belief that India will continue to grow at an exemplary 8%-plus rate in the decades to come.

headline: Glencore Highlights FTSE's Big Shift
summary: Glencore International's trading debut Thursday, and its scheduled entry into the FTSE 100 next week, highlight how the FTSE 100 has transformed over the past decade.

headline: China to Promote Renewable Energy Through Subsidies
summary: China will offer interest-rate subsidies to the renewable-energy and high-technology material sectors, to support new energy and new materials.

headline: India May Sign Jet Deal by March
summary: India may sign a contract to buy 126 fighter jets for its air force by the end of March, Defense Minister A.K. Antony said, as the south Asian country seeks to bolster its air defense capabilities to counter Pakistan and China.

headline: Windows and Water in Hong Kong
summary: In Hong Kong, houses are generally reserved for the ultrarich, but there are some relative bargains for the merely rich in the New Territories. This 2,351-square-foot townhouse is available for lease for 72,000 Hong Kong dollars (about US$9,250) a month.

headline: China's Doctored Copper Demand
summary: With credit conditions tight, importing copper has become a way for businesses to circumvent the Chinese government's lending controls.

headline: Vedanta Resources to Sell Global Bond
summary: Vedanta Resources is planning to sell a global dollar bond following a roadshow starting May 23, a person familiar with the proposed deal said. The funds raised will help the company pay for its purchase of a stake in Cairn India.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: Heat wave in India, a Kashmiri nomadic camp, laborers on a construction site, the Samjhauta Express and more.

headline: ABN Amro's Net Soars
summary: Nationalized Dutch lender ABN Amro Bank reported its net profit more than doubled in the first quarter, helped by revenue growth and cost-cutting, and said it will step up efforts to improve efficiency.

headline: IMF Selection Process Not So Simple
summary: In one sense, the selection process for the next IMF head is simple. The contender who gets a simple majority of the votes in the IMF's board wins. But in reality it's far more complex.

headline: Engine Issues Send Qantas Flight Back to Bangkok
summary: A Qantas Airways Boeing 747 bound for London returned safely to Bangkok Friday after one of its four Rolls Royce engines experienced increased vibration and high temperatures.

headline: India is a Strategic Market, Says Paper Maker
summary: Paper demand in India is forecast to increase to 14 million ton by 2015, said International Paper India President Paul Brown.

headline: German Producer Prices Rise 1%
summary: Producer prices in Germany, Europe's largest economy, rose at a faster pace in April from the month and year earlier, driven largely by higher energy prices, the Federal Statistics Office said.

headline: Kazakhstan Bank Chief Backs Change at IMF
summary: Kazakhstan's central bank governor, Grigoriy Marchenko, said it was too early to discuss his Russia-backed nomination to lead the International Monetary Fund, but stressed that emerging economies should have a bigger role in running the world's largest financial institutions.

headline: APEC Ministers Discuss Future of Doha Trade Talks
summary: Asia-Pacific trade ministers completed the first of two days of meetings on regional trade cooperation Thursday with frank talk about the increasingly shaky future of the Doha Round of global trade talks.

headline: Zhou Warns on High Savings
summary: China must be vigilant in monitoring its high savings ratio, as too high a level could lead to asset bubbles and industrial overcapacity, PBOC's Zhou said.

headline: Takeda, Toshiba Make $16 Billion M&A Push
summary: Fortified by the strong yen, Japan's Takeda Pharmaceutical agreed to buy Switzerland's Nycomed in a $13.7 billion deal, and Toshiba plans a $2.3 billion purchase of Landis+Gyr, as Japanese overseas M&A activity is on record pace this year.

headline: Unintended Pregnancies Cost Government $11 Billion a Year
summary: To the list of hot-button ideas for reducing the federal government's budget deficit, add one more: stopping unwanted pregnancies.

headline: Rosneft's Disappointing Dating Scene
summary: When you are a Russian behemoth with ties to the Kremlin, dates can be hard to come by. But with its share swap and Arctic exploration deal with BP stymied for now, Rosneft needs to at least flick through its little black book.

headline: Twombly's Travels
summary: Nine recently acquired Cy Twombly works go on view at MoMA.

headline: He Deserves a Break...
summary: An aging Ronald McDonald wants to be a Yankee.

headline: An Electrical Jolt for Paralysis Research
summary: In a potential breakthrough for the treatment of spinal-cord injuries, a man paralyzed below the chest has regained some ability to move and stand through the use of electrical stimulation coupled with intense physical rehabilitation.

headline: Spain Vote Threatens to Uncover Debt
summary: Elections that threaten to drive Spain's ruling Socialist party from power in several areas may also reveal piles of undisclosed debt in local governments.

headline: Republicans Block Judicial Nominee Liu
summary: The Senate voted against bringing the nomination of Goodwin Liu as a federal appellate judge to a floor vote, effectively blocking the law professor's chances.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Bottle
summary: Companies in China are responding to rising costs with an old strategy: smaller packaging. Sellers of milk, Coke, Pepsi, L'Oréal facial moisturizer and other products have rolled out smaller sizes while keeping prices steady.

headline: Liberty Media Bids for Barnes & Noble
summary: Barnes & Noble said John Malone's Liberty Media offered to acquire the book retailer for $1.02 billion, sending Barnes & Noble shares up sharply in after-hours trading Thursday.

headline: James Bacchus: A Rare-Earths Showdown Looms
summary: WTO litigation over China's export limits is inevitable unless Beijing comes to its senses.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Love the House, Not the Trees
summary: A reader wants to know if there's a market for unwanted backyard trees.

headline: Ian Schrager Puts His Disco Days Behind Him
summary: American hotelier Ian Schrager first shot to fame opening the now legendary Studio 54 in New York in the 1970s, but his life is considerably quieter now, with weekends spent in the Hamptons with his family.

headline: Oblique Strain Is Baseball's 'Injury of the Year'
summary: The same oblique strain that felled the Tampa Bay Rays' Evan Longoria has also hobbled Derrek Lee of the Baltimore Orioles. Having your catcher play designated hitter can carry some risks. And Jason Gay's The Couch gets ready for the Preakness.

headline: An Unfamiliar Face, Soon Everywhere
summary: By the end of the year, little-known actress Jessica Chastain will have starred in at least six new movies, from "The Tree of Life" to "The Help."

headline: Scientists Misjudged Quake Potential
summary: Scientists underestimated the seismic complexity of Japan's earthquake-prone area, and thus failed to predict the size and impact of the recent megaquake that hit the country, new research suggests.

headline: St. John's-Kentucky to Showcase Frosh
summary: The game could be the first major test for St. John's highly touted recruiting class. Plus, the Giants' owner writes about his labor views and the Yankees' Chris Dickerson is OK after getting beaned.

headline: Small Investors Predict a Stock-Market Decline
summary: Individual investors are bearish on the stock market. While some see that as a good sign, those investors have been right lately.

headline: Styling Australia's Riesling
summary: The chief executive of Australian Vintage, Neil McGuigan, talks about how the wine producer is trying to provide a "little bit of Aussie warmth and flavor."

headline: Obama's Freedom Agenda
summary: For a moment yesterday, we thought the year was 2005.

headline: Health Insurance Hikes Face Scrutiny
summary: Health insurance companies that raise premiums for individuals or small business customers 10% or more a year soon will face greater scrutiny from state or federal regulators.

headline: Goldman Braces for Subpoenas
summary: Goldman Sachs executives expect subpoenas from U.S. prosecutors seeking more information about mortgage-related business.

headline: China Pauses on High-Speed Rail
summary: China ordered a halt to construction of one of its planned high-speed rail lines because of violations to environmental regulations.

headline: Game Over for Many Baseball Teams
summary: Contradicting some of baseball's most cherished cliches, statistics show that your team's fate may well be sealed by June 1. As Yogi Berra said, "It gets late early out there."

headline: Time for Something Special
summary: When it comes towatches, the time-keeping function is secondary. The primary intent is the use of gems as design elements—creating shapes, depicting symbols and provoking emotions.

headline: Napa Valley, Korean Style
summary: A Seoul businessman spares no effort to create the perfect wine estate.

headline: No-Hitters Have Given Mets the Slip Since 1962
summary: Dillon Gee was almost halfway there before surrending a sixth-inning single in Thursday's victory over Nationals.

headline: Fed Sells Out Latest AIG Bond Offering
summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York sold all 29 subprime mortgage bonds on offer in its latest sale from a portfolio of securities acquired from American International Group.

headline: Alan Jacobs: A Bachelor's Degree in Atheism
summary: California's Pitzer College decides to investigate the phenomenon of unbelief.

headline: Christie Seeks Tighter Limits on Medicaid
summary: New Jersey is trying to deal with bulging Medicaid costs by trimming new eligibility for the government health-care program to the bare bones.

headline: Staging Stunts For Hospitals
summary: Project Sunshine's Eight Annual Benefit at Cipriani Wall Street utilized plenty of stunts to raise money for hospital children's programs.

headline: Another Federal Reserve Reform Idea
summary: I applaud John R. Dearie's letter of May 18 concerning Gerald P. O'Driscoll's op-ed piece of May 6, "Barney Frank's Latest Bad Idea." Mr. Dearie's astute analysis of the imbalance in the Federal Reserve System is spot on and timely.

headline: 'Resurrection' Brings Mahler Back to Life
summary: The Gewandhaus Orchestra's performance of Mahler's Second Symphony at the International Mahler Festival Leipzig uncorked a festival dedicated to a composer whose oeuvre has undergone a drastic critical and popular re-evaluation.

headline: Insider Trading Is Unfair to Outsiders
summary: Regarding Holman Jenkins's "Temporary Sanity in Insider-Trading Law" (Business World, May 14): When considering insider trading cases, there is a simple guideline to determine if wrongdoing occurred.

headline: The Joint Strike Fighter Needs One Engine Provider
summary: At Pratt & Whitney and United Technologies, we share House Armed Services Committee Chairmen Buck McKeon's desire to provide our warfighters the best equipment and taxpayers the best engine value to power the Joint Strike Fighter.

headline: Mine Probe Faults Massey
summary: An investigation into the Massey coal-mine explosion concluded the accident could have been prevented and was primarily the result of the failure of the company's safety systems, as well as inadequate oversight by regulators.

headline: High Price for EU Integration
summary: It's ironic that as EU politicians debate the need for ever-greater fiscal integration, regions within of the bloc's countries are talking about less. This could well have significance for how the European sovereign debt crisis pans out.

headline: A Business Traveler's Guide to Milan
summary: It may be fashionable to dismiss Milan as lacking the cultural masterpieces and splendor of cities such as Rome and Florence, but when it comes to doing business in Italy, with a little fun and entertainment thrown in for good measure, few places can beat it.

headline: Gap Gets Squeezed by Spiral of Costs
summary: Gap warned that raw-materials costs are rising faster than expected—and faster than it can raise prices—creating a squeeze that will eat into the company's profit this year.
